content.description: The crux is the summit pinnacle. Pretty good rock for an Oregon peak.
content.protection: Most people solo this. The 4th class is 30 feet. There is webbing at the top for rapping but downclimbing is not difficultÂ
content.location: Start where the Thielsen trail crosses the PCT, on the west ridge. Mostly 2nd class until you reach the summit pinnacle. then a short bit of 3rd and 4th class to reach the summit.

content.description:
Lots of big blocks all over, generally great hands with good feet. Slightly overhung in places, and the spice from the exposure is real.

 Lots of cracks for pro all over, and if you take the class 4 to the summit you can easily set up a toprope. You'll need to construct your own anchor, there are no bolts.

 If you lead this, the belayer may also want to place pro as they'll be within 3 feet of a 1500' cliff.
content.protection: Bring a large rack, or anchor gear for TR. No fixed gear or top bolts.
content.location: As you approach the summit pinnacle on the 4th class trail from below, head left instead of right. Follow the base of the summit pinnacle clockwise until you're cliffed out. There should be a small/medium ledge just before the cliff for the belayer. Route is up the arete to the summit.

content.description: I'm surprised this hasn't been submitted already. The lightning rod of the Cascades. Located a few miles north of Crater Lake. Pretty good route. Definitely worth a visit if traveling through Central Oregon.
